[[Gilles Deleuze]] and [[Félix Guattari]] write in ''[[Anti-Oedipus]]'', "capitalism garners and possesses the force of the aim and the interest (power), but it feels a disinterested love for the absurd and nonpossessed force of the machine. [...] to be sure, it is not for himself or his children that the capitalist works, but for the immortality of the system. A violence without purpose, [...] a pure joy in feeling oneself a wheel in the machine, traversed by flows, broken by schizzes".<ref>[http://books.google.es/books?id=4KCfPtku4qAC&printsec=frontcover&dq=anti-oedipus#v=onepage&q&f=false Anti-Oedipus]. P. 380.</ref> [[Michel Foucault]] insists in his 1977 Preface to the English edition of Deleuze's ''Introduction to schizoanalysis'', that he opposes to "not only fascism, but also the fascism in us all, in our heads and in our everyday behavior, the fascism that causes us to love power, to desire the very thing in our everyday behavior, the fascism that causes us to love power, to desire the very thing that dominates and exploits us".<ref>Gilles Deleuze, Eugene W. Holland. [http://books.google.es/books?id=IM_nOyU7V_UC&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false Deleuze and Guattari's Anti-Oedipus: introduction to schizoanalysis]. P. IX.</ref>

[[Humanistic psychology]] sets love as an essential requirement for a healthy [[self-esteem in humanistic psychology|self-esteem]]. [[Abraham Maslow]] places love at the ''love/belonging level'', between the ''safety level'' and the ''esteem level'', in his [[Maslow's hierarchy of needs|hierarchy of needs]].
